Feature: Are there specific vocabularies for hunting or use in the presence of avoidance kin?
Comment:
Hunting
Au Maleng: the chief in hunting and war (suku Lamadua)
Au Seken: the left chief
Au Wanan: the right chief
Lakar: place to cut the hunted animals

Feature: Is there ritual speech?
Does the ritual speech involve parallellisms, dual symbolic categories?
Is the ritual language known by everyone (or just by traditional leaders)?
Are there ritual songs?
Comment:
Geka Kelo: This is the name of the song, the dance but alos the ceremony. The ceremony takes place if a first child is born. Only females take part in this ceremony. But only people of the Lamadua clan have this ceremony in Lewaji. (In other villages it also exists. For example in Bakan only the clan Ata Ujan Batkoti has this ceremony.)
There is also a song for the rice stepping ceremony (injak padi).

Feature: Are there ritual dances?
Comment:
Traditional dances
Dese Rua: can be performed any time, it's a former war dance 
Geka Kelo: only for traditional ceremony when first child is born in the Lamadua clan, is not allowed at other times, see 10.4

Feature: Is the language of the ritual songs a language you understand?
Is the language of the ritual songs a foreign language?
Do women and men dance together?
Are there traditional ceremonies where men and women must be separated?
Comment:
There are many which are only for man but a few for women only. They are:
Geka Kelo:  see 10.4
Tobe Manuk: When a girl wants to get married, she has to sit on a chicken until it is dead, then cook it for her mother to eat. If this is not done, the mother is not allowed to eat chicken prepared by her daughter.

Feature: Is there a ceremony relating to planting/harvesting?
Comment: plantig rice, harvesting rice, stepping rice (injak padi)

Feature: Did your ancestors arrive in boats?
Comment: There are certain clans that came from the islands Lepan Batan by boat because they had to flee from a tsunami which made the islands Lepan Batan disappear.

Feature: Does sacrifice involve feeding of ancestors?
Comment: In the right corner of the rumah adat (tradition house). This is a normal house but it has a special place for sacrifice.

Feature: Is there/are  there (a) ritual place(s)?
Comment: liri wana in the tradition house (rumah adat). Pater Henrik Bala, SVD wrote about liri wana, he is now in Afrika (Congo) but comes from Kalikasa.

Feature: Did your ancestors arrive as sea animals? (shark, crocodile, turtle, dolphin)
Is there a myth about the origin of the people?
Comment: Each clan has it's origin story. The Pêwut clan is the only one which came out of the earth at a place not far from Lewaji today. The other clans mainly fled from the islands Lepan Batan which were devastated by a tsunami. The biggest clan Wawin fled from Watuwawer because of a pig meat that became stone when they wanted to eat it. People got scared and left.

Feature: Are there traditional religious leaders or specialists?
Are there traditional drinks, or stimulants?
Comment:
tuak 'palm wine'
betenuts
there is a ritual drink mixed by a dukun which is used for rituals but also for healing wounds (it contains chicken blood).

Feature: Is there a traditional sacrifice place?
Comment:
There is a place for bigger ceremonies. For example people are asking for rain during the raining season when rain is not falling. This ceremony is done at Senara (a palce with a tree and a source).
However every house also can have a place for small sacrifies for ancestors.

Feature: Are there rituals around birth?
Comment: Geka Kelo: only for Lamadua clan, see 10.4

Feature: Are there rituals around death?
Comment:
Burip: A ceremony to talk to a person which just died. Only a dukun can understand what the person has to say.
Woju Neda: It is a ceremony to find out why a person died. This is happening the next day after the death. At the grave, there will appear signs and the dukun can understand. He will say what he understands. If this is correct, the signs will be vanish but if not yet, there will be new signs appearing.

Feature: Are there seasonal rituals apart from planting and harvesting, for example is there a ritual to ask for rain? Or other rituals?
Comment: Asking for rain.

Feature: Do women traditionally weave?
Is there traditional pottery?
Are there moko?
Comment: What is moko?

Feature: Is it allowed to exchange the moko?
Are there people who make new moko?
Are there traditional music instruments?
Comment:
bamboo flutes and drums
Keweko Munung: flute made from bamboo, 5 holes (pentatonik)

Feature: Are there particular traditional music styles?
Do people use body paint or tattoo?
Were teeth traditionally filed? (i.e. made shorter with a file)
Are there typical traditional haircuts?
Traditional piercings?
Are feathers or beads used as adornments?
Is there traditional jewelry?
Is there special adornment used in rituals or ceremonies?
Is there special adornment used in rituals or ceremonies?
Is spatial organization divided into primary and secondary type?
Comment: There are terms for landswards/seawards (jae/lau) but the other two directions have the same word, both are wêli.

Feature: Are there conceptual connections between spatial directions such as E+S / W + N with male/female, or with day/night, or with right/left?
Do adults in this village typically speak more than one local language?
Do children typically speak more than one local language?
Is it common in this village that husband and wife have different languages?
Does a wife learn to speak the language of her husband?
Comment: Usually the woman is from another place and lives with her husband in Lewaji, then she will learn the local language of Lewaji to communicate and understand the other people in the village.

Feature: Does a husband learn to speak the language of his wife?
Comment: But it does not happen that often that a Lewaji woman lives with her husband from another place in Lewaji.

Feature: Do they communicate with a third language?
Comment: They also use Indonesian between each other when they have a different language background.

Feature: Do people traditionally hunt?
Comment: But is is getting less and less. The traditional hunting methods are: bow and arrow, traps, sligshot.

Feature: Do people traditionally fish in the sea?
Comment: This is a mountain area.

Feature: Do people traditionally have animal husbandry?
Comment:
pigs, goats, chicken, dogs
Chicken and dogs are kept close to the house. Pigs and goats usually at a place on the village edge or in the gardens outside the village.

Feature: Do people traditionally have agriculture?
Comment: Some garden fields are very close to village, some are a bit further but all are located in a distance which is reachable in a time that makes it possible to go there in the morning and to retunr home in the afternoon. Almost all people still have garden fields from which they live. Only people with a salary don't, these are mainly teachers. In the village, there are no other jobs which people can live of.

Feature: Intensity of cultivation?
Major crops?
Comment:
It is difficult to say which is the major crop. Everything has it's season. So there is no crop or other harvest which is all year long.
For subsistence, there is dry rice, corn, roots and tubers, vegetables and fruits (mango, pineapple, bananas, ...). To sell, they harvest coffee, cacao, cashew, coconuts, kemiri.

Feature: Are there clans?
Comment:
The biggest clan: Wawin (people that from Watuwawer, eastern part of Atadei District)
Only native clan: Pêwut (means 'bee')
Other clans: Lamadua, Bakeor, Tukan

Feature: Are there moieties?
Comment: There are subclans according to descent groups of different ancestors. Ex: Wawin Mior, Wawin Tapaleng, Wawin Bliaor, Wawin Demaor, Wawin Peaor. I am not sure if also the smaller clans have it. I am not sure of these subclans still have importance for ritual or social purpose.

Feature: Is there a concept of 'house' (uma/rumah) that equals a descent group?
Comment: Many subclans have the word or 'liver; inside' as the second part of their name. It is possible that in former times this also meant 'house'. But I don't know.

Feature: Are clans matrilineal
Are clans, subclans or lineages ranked
Comment: My informant was not sure. The only thing I can say for sure that there is only one clan which is said to be native, this is Pêwut. The other clans are newcomers to the village. But I don't know if this has any implications.

Feature: Does every clan speak their own language?
Is real property (land) inherited?
Did one person (lord / clan) originally own all the land?
Did one person (lord / clan) originally own all the land?
Comment: My informant said that those who worked hard could get more land. But I think I heard of a "tuan tana" (owner of the land) but maybe this is only simbolic. I am not sure.

Feature: Are there inheritance rules?
Comment: All male children get the same proportion. (Female children don't get anything because they are supposed to be married into another family.)

Feature: Is land inheritance matrilineal (sister's sons; sister's younger brother)?
Is land inheritance patrilineal (sons)?
Is moveable property inheritance matrilineal (sister's sons; sister's younger brother)?
Is moveable property inheritance patrilineal?
Do all children inherit, sons and daughters alike?
Do all children inherit, with daughters receiving less?
Comment: Daughters get nothing. (see 4.2)

Feature: Can newcomers aquire land or gardens?
Comment: They can buy land.

Feature: At what age should young people get married?
Comment:
This is because they need to be able financially (or in former times: have gardens, women: weaving, men: hunting) to have a family.
However today, my informant said, many people marry too young because the woman gets pregnant.

Feature: Are there marriage rules – specify in notes field
Comment:
People have to marry outside their own clan. The clans are put into 3 groups with similar number of people and these groups are arranged in triagle. That means that no direct exchange of women between two clans in possible. For example Wawin men take Tukan women but Tukan men cannot take Wawin women.
Lewaji marriage system:
Wawin men take Tukan women - 
Tukan men take Bakeor/Pêwut/Lamadua women -
Bakeor/Pêwut/Lamadua men take Wawin women

Feature: Is there gift exchange between bride's and groom's sides?
Comment: not very clear how this differs from 5.8 and 5.9

Feature: Is there bride service?
Transfer of residence at marriage?
Comment:
The wife moves to the husband's clan but they will build their own house there.
But in case the bride price is not payed yet, it is possible that the man moves to the women's parents and they live together with the women's parents. Some couples also have children when still living with the women's family.

Feature: Marital residence with kin?
Comment: see also 5.12

Feature: Are traditional marriages obligatorily exogamous?
Comment: see also 5.1

Feature: If mother dies, who raises the children?
Possible Values: 12:Father and his family.;10:Father and/or his family;11:Mother and/or her family

Feature: Does a man typically marry a woman of his mother's subclan?
Comment: A man can marry the descendants of his mother's brother (the mother's brother is addressed om (IND) or opo (local langauge). However, only after three generations. It is thus not possible to marry a first grade cousin (It may be that this is a new rule which came with the church and government.). This confirms the rule above in 5.1 because for example a Wawin man has a father from Wawin but his mother will be from the Tukan clan.

Feature: Does a woman typicaly marry a man of her father’s subclan?
Are there locality-based restrictions on marriage
Was polygamy permitted
Was polyandry permitted?
Is bridewealth paid by the groom's side to the bride's side
Comment: balar 'ivory'

Feature: Is dowry paid by the bride's side to the groom's side
Comment: traditional sarong, jewlery

Feature: Are villages the typical settlement pattern?
Are dispersed solitary family homesteads the typical settlement pattern?
Are settlements permanent?
Are villages/hamlets centered on a group of related women
Mean size of local communities?
Comment: 458 residents

Feature: Are villages/hamlets centered on a group of related men?
Comment: Nowadays settling is rather free but in the past there have been settlements according to clan affiliation.

Feature: Are villages/hamlets (traditionally) located on hill tops?
Are villages/hamlets (tradtionally) located on the shore?
Do villages have places or spaces for gatherings?
Comment:
Today there is a church which can be used but also private houses are used for meetings.
Lewaji is a quiet recent settlement (since 1968). Before that they lived at a place close by (the old village, kampung lama) but that place bacame to small. Maybe in that village there was still a ritual gorund?

Feature: Shape of (traditional) houses?
Floor level of traditional houses?
Shape of roof of traditional houses?
Is there an attic or loft in a traditional house?
Do leaders come from particular lineages?
Comment: Any male clan member can become clan head. He is elected by (male?) clan members.

Feature: Are leaders non-hereditary?
Are there groups with whom traditional relations are forbidden?
Are there groups with whom there has been war?
Comment:
Enemy villages: Lêwukedukak and Lewewe
There was also war with Lebala (a kingdom during Dutch colonial times). This war was ended by a merriage of a Lewaji woman (Pêwut clan) with a Lebala man.

Feature: Is there an opposition between people of the interior and people of the shore?
Comment: Traditional ceromies are different. People of Lewaji are Ata Kiwan 'mountain people'. People of the cost are called Ata Watan 'beach people'.

Feature: Are there female community/clan leaders
Are there men’s houses
Comment: But only for the Wawin clan.

Feature: Are there (traditional)   rulers/kings?
Are there slaves?
Is there a concept for both ruler and foreigner, stranger king?
Are there traditional relations/alliances with one or more neighbouring groups?
Comment: They one invited a dukun from another place to fight two other villages that was always stronger than Lewaji.

Feature: Is there a special name for this alliance?
Is namesake ritually marked, or with features reminiscent of particular kinship relations?
Comment: People get usually two name. The first one is the baptist name, a Christian name. The second is a name of an ancestor. The first male child gets the name of the father's father. The first female chidl gets the name of the father's mother. The second child gets a name from the matrilinear grandparents.
Possible Values: 10:Given Abui name upon birth given by  parents;0:No;1:Yes

Feature: Do descent groups own sets of personal names?
Are names taken from the father's group?
Comment: But only for the first child. See also 9.

Feature: Are names taken from the mother's group?
Comment: But only the second (male or feamle) child. See also 9.

Feature: Are there name taboos?
Are there particular relations not to be addressed, or mentioned, by name
did your language (or a group of people defined by speaking the language) traditionally have a name, other than a locality name
Comment:
The language is only named after places. The origin of the variety used in Lewaji is Bakan. So it is Bahasa Bakan (Bakan langauge). However, people in other villages with the same language don't say they speak Bakan but in Lewaji they say they speak Lewajin and in Kalikasa they say they speak Kalikasan, and so on.
Villages using the language coming from Bakan: Waimuda, Kalikasa, Kolilerek, Bakan, Lewaji, Mudalerek (all in the western part of Atadei District).

Feature: Is there a special word to refer to a foreigner?
Comment: Kari Pana 'newcomer/immigrant' literally 'run go'
